results.name: Full_Crash
results.title: Full Crash
results.description:
The main source of the crash data is owned and maintained by the Virginia Department of Motor Vehicle (DMV).┬áDMV’s Traffic Records┬áElectronic Data System (TREDS) is a state-of-the-art data system maintained by the DMV Highway Safety┬áOffice (HSO) that automates and centralizes all crash data in Virginia.┬á┬áPer┬ádata sharing use agreement┬áwith DMV, VDOT publishes the non-privileged crash data through Virginia Roads data portal.┬áIn providing this data, VDOT assumes no responsibility for the accuracy and completeness of the data. In the process of recording and compiling the data, some deletions and/or omissions of data may occur and VDOT is not responsible for any such occurrences. The most recent data contained in this dataset is preliminary and subject to change. You can download data┬áhere.


Please be advised that, under Title 23 United State Code – Section 407, this crash information cannot be used in discovery or as evidence in a Federal or State court proceeding or considered for other purposes in any action for damages against VDOT or the State of Virginia arising from any occurrence at the location identified.

All users shall comply with and be subject to all applicable laws and regulations, whether federal or state, in connection with any of the receipt and use of DMV data including, but not limited to, (1) the Federal Drivers Privacy Protection Act (18 U.S.C. ┬º 2721 et seq.), (2) the Government Data Collection and Dissemination Practices Act (Va. Code ┬º 2.2-3800 et seq.), (3) the Virginia Computer Crimes Act (Va. Code ┬º 18.2-152.1 et seq.), (4) the provisions of Va. Code ┬º┬º 46.2-208 and 58.1-3, and (5) any successor rules, regulations, or guidelines adopted by DMV with regard to disclosure or dissemination of any information obtained from DMV records or files.
results.snippet: This feature layer contains point locations and related data for all reportable motor vehicle crashes.

In the process of recording and compiling the data, some deletions and/or omissions of data may occur and VDOT is not responsible for any such occurrences. The most recent data contained in this report is preliminary and subject to change.┬á┬á

All users shall comply with and be subject to all applicable laws and regulations, whether federal or state, in connection with any of the receipt and use of DMV data including, but not limited to, (1) the Federal Drivers Privacy Protection Act (18 U.S.C. ┬º 2721 et seq.), (2) the Government Data Collection and Dissemination Practices Act (Va. Code ┬º 2.2-3800 et seq.), (3) the Virginia Computer Crimes Act (Va. Code ┬º 18.2-152.1 et seq.), (4) the provisions of Va. Code ┬º┬º 46.2-208 and 58.1-3, and (5) any successor rules, regulations, or guidelines adopted by DMV with regard to disclosure or dissemination of any information obtained from DMV records or files.

Any person, organization, firm, corporation or other entity using this database does so at its own risk. In addition, the Virginia Department of Transportation does not guarantee system availability and is not responsible for any losses associated with any system unavailability. VDOT's digital data files are for use in performing the official business of the Commonwealth of Virginia. VDOT Divisions set all policy on the allowable uses of this data. The representations of VDOT business data contained within are believed to be correct. This data is provided without any guarantee of accuracy, timeliness or completeness. results.name: Oahu_Crashes_2007to2016
results.title: Oahu_Crashes_2007to2016
results.description:
Oahu Traffic Crash Locations 2007-2016 By Year and Mode

Source:
Hawaii Dept. of Health, EMS and Injury Prevention System Branch

This map summarizes the locations of EMS-attended motor vehicle crashes on Oahu,for each of the 4 modes of crashes: automobiles (cars, trucks, and buses), motorcycles or mopeds, pedestrians, and bicyclists hit by motor vehicles. Bicyclists who were injured from crashes that did not involve a motor vehicle, i.e. by falling off their bikes, were not included. This distinction only became available in EMS data in 2009, so only bicycle crashes from 2009 through 2011 were included.

The data source for this report are the patient care reports completed electronically at the crash scene by City and County of Honolulu EMS providers. (This excludes reports submitted by EMS agencies for Hickam Air Force Base and Pearl Harbor Naval Base.) City and County personnel responded to 14,669 crashes over the 5-year period, of which 14,121 (96%) could be mapped or geocoded. Geocoding was accomplished by linking the patient care report to latitude and longitude recorded by the EMS Communications Center at the time of the 911 call. The crash “location” is therefore the location of the 911 caller, although this is assumed to usually be in the proximity of the actual crash. The crash location was plotted using ESRI ArcGIS geographic information system software. Geocoded crash locations that were within 50 feet of each other were merged to a common final location, for a more manageable description of clusters.

A maps book depicting crashes by neighborhood board district can be found here:┬á┬áhttps://health.hawaii.gov/injuryprevention/home/reports-maps-data/library/.
results.snippet:
Oahu Traffic Crash Locations 
2007-2016 By Year and Mode
results.accessInformation: Hawaii Statewide GIS Program, Hawaii Dept. of Health, EMS and Injury Prevention System Branch
results.licenseInfo:
State of Hawaii Terms of Use:┬á┬áhttps://portal.ehawaii.gov/page/terms-of-use/

There are no expressed warranties associated with the release of this data or product. Specifically, no warranty is made that the GIS data or any subsequent updates will be error free and no warranty is made regarding the positional or thematic accuracy of the GIS data. The GIS data and any features depicted do not represent or confer any legal rights, privileges, benefits, boundaries or claims of any kind. The Office of Planning encourages users to report any discrepancies or errors found. results.name: High_Crash_Segments_2016_2020
results.title: High Crash Segments 2016-2020
results.description:
This layer shows the high crash segments in Cleveland using crash data from 2016 to 2020. Crashes resulting in serious injuries or death are used to determine if a segment qualifies as a high-crash segment. In order to qualify, there must be 10 or more serious injury or fatal crashes in any 5-year period. Generally, one-mile segments with 10 or more serious or fatal crashes represent particularly dangerous road segments on the city's network.

Crash data is obtained from ODOT: Crash Analysis Tools | ODOT

Documentation and Definitions
See data table. Also, ODOT provides a data glossary: Crash Data Dictionary | ODOT

Update Frequency
Not updated. See subsequent layers for more recent data.

Contact
Cameron Roberts, Vision Zero Coordinator
croberts5@clevelandohio.gov
results.snippet: High crash street segments in Cleveland based on crash activity during 2016-2020.
results.licenseInfo: Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL)

results.name: CRASHES__2024
results.title: CRASHES - 2024
results.description:
Crashes occur due to a combination of factors related to the roadway user, the vehicle, and the roadway. All of these factors must be considered when developing projects or programs with the intent to enhance safety and reduce fatalities and serious injuries. The department's safety related initiatives were developed and are refined with this in mind and are consistent with the Strategic Highway Safety Plan.
 
 
More information about IDOT’s Roadway Crash Data can be found at the Illinois Transportation Safety site.
results.licenseInfo:

Since all boundaries and all data are based on information derived from multiple sources within and outside the Illinois Department of Transportation, the Department of Transportation and the State of Illinois make no representation, guarantee, or warrant, either express or implied, regarding the accuracy of these maps or the data furnished thereon, including, but not limited to, the condition of this product, this product's merchantability, or this product's fitness for any particular purpose or use.

results.name: FLIntCrashRates
results.title: Florida High Crash Intersections - 2013
results.description:
This layer represents high crash intersections┬áon the Florida State Highway System (SHS) with their 5-year crash rates as analyzed by the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT) State Safety Office’s Crash Analysis Reporting (CAR) system. A high crash intersection in one in which there were a minimum of 8 crashes during the analysis period and the intersection "confidence" is at least 95% for rural intersections, 99% for suburban intersections or 99.95% for urban intersections. The confidence indicates how certain the State Safety Office is that the crash rate at the intersection is above the average, accounting for traffic volume and crash frequency.┬á It is determined by comparing the intersection's crash rate with the average within the FDOT Managing District for similar types of intersections.

The rates are computed only for intersections which are included on the Florida State Highway System. The crashes included in the rate calculation are only those reported by a law enforcement officer on the Florida Traffic Crash Report - Long Form and located by FDOT Analysts. A crash rate is calculated by dividing the number of crashes within 250 feet of the intersection during the analysis period (2009 to 2013) by the number of vehicles passing through the intersection during the analysis period. A higher crash rate indicates that more crashes are occurring┬áat the intersections┬áper the number of vehicles which are estimated to be traveling through the intersection.

If you have any questions or comments, please contact:
Shaun Davis
Florida Department of Transportation – State Safety Office
605 Suwannee Street
Tallahassee, Florida 32399
850-414-4075 or shaun.davis@dot.state.fl.us
results.snippet: This layer represents mapped roadway "high crash" intersections on the Florida State Highway System (SHS) with the 5-year crash rates as analyzed by the Florida DOT.

It contains information that is to be used to develop highway safety improvement projects. Access to the information contained in this file, or otherwise originating from the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT), Safety Office or from the Crash Analysis Reporting (CAR) System is restricted to government agencies and to employees of government agencies working on projects that require access to crash report data. For exceptions, apply to FDOT Safety Office. The information contained in this file, or otherwise originating from the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT), Safety Office or from the Crash Analysis Reporting (CAR) System shall be used only for those purposes deemed appropriate by the FDOT. See Title 23, United States Code, section 409.

NO WARRANTIES: This map and its content is made available by the Florida Department of Transportation on an “as is,” “as available” basis without warranties of any kind, express or implied.

Disclaimer: MassDOT makes no representation as to the accuracy, adequacy, reliability, availability or completeness of the crash records or the data collected from them and is not responsible for any errors or omissions in such records or data. Under no circumstance will MassDOT have any liability for any loss or damage incurred by any party as a result of the use of the crash records or the data collected from them. Furthermore, the data contained in the web-based crash report tool are not an official record of what transpired in a particular crash or for a particular crash type. If a user is interested in an official copy of a crash report, contact the Registry (http://www.mass.gov/rmv/). The data posted on this website, including crash records and other reports, are collected for the purpose of identifying, evaluating or planning the safety enhancement of potential crash sites, hazardous roadway conditions or railway-highway crossings. Under federal law, this information is not subject to discovery and cannot be admitted into evidence in any federal or state court proceeding or considered for other purposes in any action for damages that involves the sites mentioned in these records (see 23 USC, Section 407).
results.snippet: Crash reports for the Northern Middlesex region from MassDOT IMPACT crash data. Includes top 100 high crash intersections and bicycle/pedestrian crash reports.

results.name: Crash_Cushions_(Active)
results.title: Crash Cushions (Active)
results.description:
A crash cushion is a disposable device used to increase safety for motor vehicle operators and passengers who collide with safety barriers at gore points. Crash cushions improve safety and also help protect the transportation infrastructure.

Displays crash cushions maintained by the Seattle Department of Transportation.

Is a view of this layer:┬áLink

Uses this recommended filter for┬ágeneral use of the dataset:┬á'CURRENT_STATUS = 'INSVC'┬áOR CURRENT_STATUS is empty string'

Refresh Cycle:┬á

Feature Class: SDOT.V_CRASHCUSHIONS
results.snippet: Displays crash cushions maintained by the Seattle Department of Transportation.
results.accessInformation: City of Seattle, Seattle Department of Transportation
results.licenseInfo: The City of Seattle makes no representation or warranty as to its accuracy, and in particular, its accuracy as to labeling, dimensions, contours, property boundaries, or placement or location of any map feature thereof.

results.name: ETDM_roadway
results.title: Florida State Roadway 5 Year Crash Rates - 2013
results.description:
This layer represents mapped roadway segments on the Florida State Highway System (SHS) with their 5-year crash rates as analyzed by the Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT) Safety Office’s Crash Analysis Reporting (CAR) system.

This dataset has been limited to roadways which:

  • are greater than 0.1 mile in length
  • are not a ramp
  • had at least 1 crash during the analysis period
  • had an AADT of 500 vehicles or greater
  • had a crash rate greater than 0
  • The rates are computed only for roadways which are included on the Florida State Highway System. The crashes included in the rate calculation are only those reported by a law enforcement officer on the Florida Traffic Crash Report - Long Form and located by FDOT Analysts. A crash rate is calculated by dividing the number of crashes on the roadway segment during the analysis period (2009 to 2013) by the segment's Average Annual Daily Traffic. A higher crash rate indicates that more crashes are occurring on a roadway segment per the number of vehicles which are estimated to be traveling on the roadway segment.
results.snippet: This layer represents mapped roadway segments on the Florida State Highway System (SHS) with their 5-year crash rates as analyzed by the Florida DOT Safety Office’s Crash Analysis Reporting (CAR) system.

results.name: FARS_Fatal_Motor_Vehicle_Accidents_2019_to_2023
results.title: FARS Fatal Motor Vehicle Crashes 2019 to 2023
results.description:
This layer contains 2019-2023 fatal motor vehicle accidents data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA)'s Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS). This point data contains fatal motor vehicle traffic crashes within the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The initial view of this layer is set to clustering to show the distrubtion of fatal motor vehicle crashes by the time of data. Zoom in to see individual crash locations.
 
Data currency: 1/1/2023
Data Uploaded: 6/18/2025
Data source: NHTSA File Downloads
For more information about FARS: Fatality Analysis Reporting System, Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) 2022 - Accidents, Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) 2023 - Accidents
Support documentation for field definitions & domains: Fatality Analysis Reporting System Analytical User’s Manual, 1975-2023, Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) Auxiliary Datasets Analytical User’s Manual 1982-2019

For feedback, please contact: saviles@esri.com

 

Bureau of Transportation Statistics

 
Per BTS, "The Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) was conceived, designed, and developed by the National Center for Statistics and Analysis (NCSA) of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in 1975 to provide an overall measure of highway safety, to help identify traffic safety problems, to suggest solutions, and to help provide an objective basis to evaluate the effectiveness of motor vehicle safety standards and highway safety programs.

The Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) 2023 Final Release - Fatal Motor Vehicle Accidents dataset was compiled from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023 by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and is part of the U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT)/Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) National Transportation Atlas Database (NTAD). This geospatial dataset is the accident file from the FARS 2023 Final Release Data. The Final Release Data is published 12-15 months, after the initial release of FARS, and could contain additional fatal accidents due to the delay in police reporting, toxicology reports, etc., along with changes to attribute information for previously reported fatal accidents. This data file contains information about crash characteristics and environmental conditions at the time of the crash. There is one record per crash. A data dictionary, or other source of attribute information, is accessible at https://doi.org/10.21949/1529018."

Esri Data Processing Notes:
  • This feature layer contains accident point data containing information about crash characteristics and environmental conditions at the time of the crash from USDOT BTS's Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) 2023 - Accidents, Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) 2022 - Accidents, and NHTSA file downloads for 2019-2021.
  • Data for 2019-2023 were merged together in ArcGIS Pro.
  • The Accidents Auxiliary File was joined to this feature layer for 2023 and 2023 data. That file contain elements derived from the FARS datasets to make it easier to extract certain data classifications and topical areas.
  • The Person Auxiliary File was added via related table to this feature layer. The Person File contains information about each person involved in a fatal motor vehicle crash. This file includes data on their role in the crash such as (driver, passenger, etc.), injury severity, and restraint use.
  • The Vehicle Auxiliary File was added via related table to this feature layer. The Vehicle File provides detailed information about the vehicles involved in the fatal motor vehicle crash.
  • Coded Domains were added to any Type/Category fields that contained numeric coded values. Descriptive values were derived from the supporting field manuals.
  • Additional fields were calculated and added by Esri as value-adds. These fields are (Date of Crash, Rush Hour, Time of Crash) and are denoted by "Esri Calculated" in the field description.
results.snippet: This layer contains 2019-2023 fatal motor vehicle accidents data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA)'s Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS). This point data contains fatal motor vehicle traffic crashes within the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The initial view of this layer is set to clustering to show the distrubtion of fatal motor vehicle crashes by the time of data. Zoom in to see individual crash locations.
